title: Production Bug Debugging Quiz
description: Test your knowledge of debugging production-only issues.

questions.question: A bug appears in production but not on your local machine. What is the most common cause?

options.text: Your local machine is broken
Environment differences (browser version, OS, data, caching, network)
The production server has malware
The user is lying about the bug

questions.explanation: Environment differences are the most common cause: different browser versions, operating systems, screen sizes, cached assets, network conditions, or different data states between local and production.

questions.question: What information should you gather from the user who reported the bug?

options.text: Just the error message
Browser, OS, screen size, steps to reproduce, screenshots or video, and any error messages
Their internet speed only
Their email address to send them a fix

questions.explanation: Comprehensive bug reports include: browser and version, operating system, device/screen size, exact steps to reproduce, expected vs actual behavior, screenshots or video, and console errors if available.

questions.question: If you can't reproduce a bug, it probably doesn't exist and can be closed.
questions.explanation: Inability to reproduce doesn't mean the bug doesn't exist. It often means you haven't replicated the exact conditions. Investigate environment differences, data states, timing issues, and caching before dismissing a report.

questions.question: Which tool helps capture JavaScript errors from real users in production?

options.text: ESLint
Sentry or LogRocket
Prettier
webpack

questions.explanation: Sentry captures JavaScript errors with stack traces, browser info, and user context from production users. LogRocket adds session replay, showing exactly what the user did when the error occurred.

questions.question: What is a 'feature flag' and how does it help with production bugs?

options.text: A visual indicator on the page showing which features are active
A toggle that enables/disables features without redeploying, allowing quick rollback of problematic features
A flag in the database that marks bugs as fixed
A type of CSS class for feature sections

questions.explanation: Feature flags let you toggle features on/off without deploying new code. If a new feature causes a production bug, you can instantly disable it while you investigate, minimizing user impact.

questions.question: A user reports a layout bug on their iPad. What's the most effective debugging approach?

options.text: Tell the user to use a desktop browser instead
Use browser DevTools responsive mode to simulate the iPad viewport, and test with Safari's rendering engine
Ignore it since iPads are a small percentage of users
Add CSS that hides the broken section on iPads

questions.explanation: Use DevTools responsive mode to match the iPad's viewport and test with Safari/WebKit rendering (since iPads use Safari's engine). Also check for Safari-specific CSS differences like viewport units (svh vs vh) and flexbox quirks.
